docs.title: Project Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the NaviSense project docs! Here you'll find key artifacts and design information.

docs.title: How To Use
docs.text:
Using the NaviSense DocTree is simple. You are already on the home page of the documentation, and accessing any document related to the project and its codebase can be done here.

Each main document can be found on this home page and is given their own section along with a short description. All the subsections of the DocTree can also be accessed through the Section List by the left side of this page (as you can no doubt verify).

The documentation is deployed through Mkdocs. This means that each page, or document for that matter, found in this documentation, other than links to PDFs, is generated from markdown files. The structure of this DocTree is defined in mkdocs.yml which can be found in the root folder of the codebase. The Sections can be found within the codebase under root/docs/ and it is here where any changes to the Documentation can be made. Adding new Sections requires only the creation of a new markdown file and for that file to also be added to the mkdocs.yml.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Start here with the overall aim, scope, and other information about the project.

  • Project Description

docs.title: Decisions
docs.text:
The following document describes major design decisions along with their drivers. This includes the information like dependencies and technology chosen for the product on the basis of aspects like information about the end-user and cost of development.

  • Design Decisions

docs.title: A Guide to Our Collaborative Process
docs.text:
This document outlines the development methodology, communication channels, and collaborative practices for our project. The aim is to agree on shared methods of working to improve collaboration efficiency.

The key topics covered are: - Two-Week Sprint Cycle - Communication Channels - Knowledge Management

docs.title: Two-Week Sprint Cycle
docs.text: The project follows an agile development framework centered around two-week sprints. The team works backwards from high-level objectives, breaking them into manageable tasks while allowing flexibility to adapt to issues as they arise.

docs.title: 1. Sprint Planning
docs.text: At the beginning (or end) of each two-week cycle, the team reviews the project backlog and selects tasks for the upcoming sprint. The goal is to ensure: - A realistic workload - Clear and well-defined objectives

docs.title: 2. Development
docs.text: During the sprint, development proceeds according to the communication and coding guidelines defined in later sections.

docs.title: 3. Sprint Review
docs.text:
At the end of each sprint, the team conducts the following activities:

a. Review Each developer presents a brief demo of their work and records any feedback from the client or team members.

b. Retrospective The team reflects on: - What worked well - What could be improved - Any obstacles encountered

c. Backlog Update Completed items are signed off, and new tasks are added based on sprint outcomes.

docs.title: Project Backlog
docs.text:
The sprint process relies on a Project Backlog, maintained as: - A simple spreadsheet, or - A task management tool such as Trello or Asana

Each backlog item should include: - A brief description - Priority level (High / Medium / Low) - Estimated effort

docs.title: Communication Channels
docs.text: The team uses multiple communication channels to keep discussions organized and easy to reference.

docs.title: Discord: Development Hub
docs.text: Discord serves as the primary development communication platform.

docs.title: 1. Formal Discussions Log
docs.text:
All technical and design discussions must be logged in a dedicated Discussions channel to create a searchable decision history. This also applies to development issues where feedback from the team is needed.

Each discussion should follow this structure:

  • Discussion Topic Brief description of the topic Example: Issue A – User Authentication Problem

  • Topic Description Clear scope of the issue Example: As part of feature X, we must implement user authentication. I am encountering problem Y.

  • Discussion Messages Messages exchanged between team members

  • Decision Summary A final post summarizing the agreed outcome of the discussion

docs.title: 2. Information Hub
docs.text: The main Discord channel contains links to essential project resources, including: - GitHub repository - OneDrive - Other relevant tools

docs.title: WhatsApp: Social and Personal Coordination
docs.text: WhatsApp is reserved for informal and logistical communication, including: - Checking in on team well-being - Coordinating meetings - Non-technical discussions

docs.title: Communication with the Client
docs.text:
• Client communication occurs at the start of each sprint cycle
  • During the first sprint, objectives are communicated via email to: j.pintado@student.tue.nl
  • For subsequent sprints, emails should include:
  • Progress update from the previous sprint
  • Objectives for the upcoming sprint

Email subject format:

Sprint Cycle # Update

(where # is the sprint number)

docs.title: Monthly Updates
docs.text:
• Updates on other events (e.g., TU/e contest) are sent on the first day of each month
  • Updates should include current progress and reflections

docs.title: Meetings
docs.text:
Full-team meetings occur: - At the beginning of the year - Before the Midterm Presentation - Before Demo Day

Additional questions or requests where the client can help may be handled via WhatsApp.

docs.title: Knowledge Management
docs.text: This section describes how the team captures and maintains knowledge throughout the project.

docs.title: Cloud OneDrive
docs.text:
The shared OneDrive stores all non-code project assets, ensuring access to the latest versions.

Contents include: - Project Foundations – project descriptions, user personas, and long-term vision documents - Past Context – reports and materials from previous years - Research and Research Briefs – sources and research materials - Design and Architecture – detailed architecture and design documents - Organizational Documents – project backlog and sprint planning files

docs.title: GitHub Repository
docs.text: All code is managed through a shared GitHub repository using a structured workflow.

docs.title: 1. Feature Branch Workflow
docs.text:
• New features must be developed on a branch created from the main development branch
  • Branches should follow the naming convention: feature-x-branch Example: user-login-branch

docs.title: 2. Merge Requests
docs.text:
• Once a feature is complete and tested locally, a merge request is opened
  • Each merge request must include:
  • A clear description of the changes
  • Relevant context for reviewers

docs.title: 3. Meaningful Commit Messages
docs.text:
Clear and descriptive commit messages are mandatory.

For significant feature work, commit messages should follow this structure:

[Task or Feature Name]

Feature Description: I implemented the user registration endpoint by creating a new service and repository in the auth module.

Next Steps: To complete the user login feature, I still need to implement token generation.

docs.title: Design Decisions
docs.text: Hello World!
